introduction.hook: In October 2016, the Mirai botnet launched the largest DDoS attack in history, taking down Twitter, Netflix, Reddit, and CNN by flooding Dyn's DNS infrastructure with traffic from millions of compromised IoT devices. Network attacks strike at the foundation of connectivity itself—without networks, modern organizations simply cannot function. Understanding how attackers exploit network protocols, intercept traffic, and overwhelm services is essential for defending the digital highways that connect everything.
learning_goals: Identify DoS, DDoS, and amplification attack techniques
Analyze man-in-the-middle attacks (ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing)
Understand on-path attacks and session hijacking
Detect network attacks using packet analysis
Implement appropriate defenses against network-based threats
introduction.why_it_matters: Networks carry all data and enable all communication. Network attacks can intercept sensitive data, disrupt operations, and redirect traffic. As a security professional, you'll configure firewalls, implement segmentation, and respond to network incidents. The Security+ exam covers network attacks extensively—expect 6-8 questions.

career_relevance.soc_analyst: You'll investigate alerts for network attacks like DDoS, ARP spoofing, and DNS anomalies. Understanding attack patterns helps you distinguish real attacks from false positives and assess severity.
career_relevance.incident_responder: Network forensics is crucial for investigations. You'll analyze packet captures, trace attack origins, and determine what data may have been intercepted or exfiltrated.
career_relevance.grc_analyst: Understanding network attack risks helps you assess controls and compliance. DDoS resilience, network segmentation, and encryption requirements are common audit topics.
career_relevance.penetration_tester: Network attacks are part of your toolkit. You'll conduct ARP spoofing, MITM attacks, and network reconnaissance during engagements to test defenses.
career_relevance.security_engineer: You'll implement IDS/IPS, configure firewalls, design network segmentation, and deploy DDoS protection. Understanding attacks helps you tune detection and prevention.

linux_fundamentals.why_it_matters: Network analysis and monitoring are essential security skills. These commands help you capture, analyze, and troubleshoot network traffic.

examples: sudo tcpdump -i eth0                    # Capture on interface
sudo tcpdump -i eth0 -w capture.pcap   # Save to file
sudo tcpdump -i eth0 port 80           # Filter by port
sudo tcpdump -i eth0 host 192.168.1.1  # Filter by host
tshark -r capture.pcap -Y 'http'      # Filter pcap for HTTP

network_monitoring.purpose: Monitor ARP table for changes (detects ARP spoofing)

sections.title: Denial of Service Attacks

content.overview: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks make systems unavailable by overwhelming resources or exploiting vulnerabilities. DDoS attacks use multiple sources, making them much harder to mitigate.

dos_categories.description: Flood target with traffic to consume bandwidth
dos_categories.defense: Upstream filtering, DDoS mitigation services, overprovisioning

dos_categories.description: Exploit protocol weaknesses to exhaust server resources
dos_categories.defense: SYN cookies, rate limiting, firewall rules

dos_categories.description: Target application vulnerabilities with legitimate-looking requests

how_it_works: 2. Server responds with SYN-ACK, allocates resources
common_techniques.detection: Many half-open connections, high SYN packet rate
common_techniques.defense: SYN cookies, SYN proxy, connection rate limiting

common_techniques.mechanism: Sends large volumes of UDP packets
how_it_works: 1. Attacker sends UDP to random ports
common_techniques.detection: High UDP traffic, many ICMP unreachable responses

common_techniques.mechanism: Keeps HTTP connections open with partial requests
common_techniques.detection: Many long-lived HTTP connections, partial headers
common_techniques.defense: Request timeout, connection limits, reverse proxy

ddos_characteristics.description: Distributed DoS uses multiple attack sources

amplification_attacks.concept: Small request generates large response sent to spoofed victim IP
amplification_attacks.prevention: Don't expose amplifiable services to internet, BCP38 (source address validation)

visualization.title: DDoS Attack Flow
diagram: ║   Bot sends small request with SPOOFED source IP (victim's IP)             ║
║   Reflector (DNS/NTP server) sends LARGE response to victim                ║

key_points: DoS = single source; DDoS = distributed (multiple sources/botnet)
SYN flood exploits TCP handshake with half-open connections
Amplification attacks use spoofed IPs to multiply attack volume
exam_tips: DoS vs DDoS: D = Distributed (many sources)
SYN flood = half-open connections exhausting table
Slowloris = slow HTTP requests, low bandwidth required
Amplification = small request → large response to victim
Know amplification factors: Memcached > NTP > DNS

glossary_terms.definition: DoS attack exploiting TCP handshake by sending SYN packets without completing connection.
glossary_terms.exam_note: Creates half-open connections. Defense: SYN cookies.

glossary_terms.definition: DDoS technique using protocols that generate large responses to small requests, directed at spoofed victim IP.
glossary_terms.exam_note: Uses DNS, NTP, Memcached. Multiplies attacker bandwidth.

knowledge_check.question: An attacker sends small DNS queries to many open resolvers with the source IP spoofed to the victim's address. What type of attack is this?
knowledge_check.explanation: This is a DNS amplification attack. Small DNS queries generate large responses (up to 70x amplification). By spoofing the source IP to the victim's address, all responses are sent to the victim, multiplying the attacker's bandwidth.

sections.title: Man-in-the-Middle and On-Path Attacks

content.overview: Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) or on-path attacks position the attacker between communicating parties, allowing interception, modification, or injection of traffic.

mitm_concept.description: Attacker intercepts communication between two parties
prerequisites: Often requires being on same network segment

how_it_works: 2. Associates attacker's MAC with gateway IP
3. Victim's traffic goes to attacker instead of gateway
5. All victim traffic passes through attacker
2. Returns malicious IP instead of real IP
4. Attacker can phish credentials or serve malware

variants.name: Local DNS Spoofing
variants.method: Responds to queries on local network

how_it_works: 1. Attacker creates fake WiFi AP with same name

techniques.name: Session Token Theft
techniques.method: Steal cookie/token via MITM or XSS

techniques.name: Session Fixation
techniques.method: Force victim to use attacker-known session ID

replay_attacks.description: Capturing and retransmitting valid authentication or commands

key_points: MITM/On-path attacks intercept communication between parties
ARP spoofing redirects LAN traffic through attacker (Layer 2)
DNS spoofing returns malicious IPs for domain lookups
SSL stripping downgrades HTTPS to HTTP to intercept credentials
Session hijacking takes over authenticated sessions

career_callout.note: ARP spoofing and MITM are common internal network assessment techniques. Tools like Ettercap, Bettercap, and arpspoof enable these attacks. Always ensure you have explicit authorization and limit scope to avoid impacting production systems.

exam_tips: ARP spoofing = Layer 2, redirects LAN traffic via fake ARP replies
DNS spoofing = returns wrong IP for domain name
Evil Twin = fake WiFi access point
Replay attack = capture and retransmit valid auth

content.description: Learn to detect ARP spoofing attacks on your network.

lab_arp_detection.title: Lab: Monitor for ARP Spoofing
lab_arp_detection.objective: Detect potential ARP spoofing on local network

steps.what_to_look_for: Duplicate MAC addresses for different IPs = ARP spoofing indicator

alerts: flip flop = MAC changed for IP
new station = new device on network

steps.suspicious: Many ARP replies from same MAC, ARP for gateway IP

commands: # Compare gateway MAC in ARP table to expected

defensive_actions: Enable Dynamic ARP Inspection (DAI) on switches
Use static ARP entries for critical systems

knowledge_check.question: An attacker on a local network sends fake ARP replies to associate their MAC address with the default gateway's IP. What attack is this?
knowledge_check.explanation: This is ARP spoofing (also called ARP poisoning). By sending fake ARP replies, the attacker causes victims to send traffic to the attacker's MAC address instead of the real gateway. This enables man-in-the-middle attacks on the local network.

sections.title: Other Network Attacks

content.overview: Beyond DoS and MITM, attackers use various techniques to exploit network infrastructure, routing, and wireless communications.

infrastructure_attacks.description: Bypassing VLAN segmentation to access other VLANs

techniques.name: Switch Spoofing
techniques.method: Attacker negotiates trunk link with switch

techniques.name: Double Tagging
techniques.method: Packet with two VLAN tags; outer stripped, inner processed

defense: Native VLAN not used for data

infrastructure_attacks.description: Overwhelming switch MAC table to cause broadcast behavior
how_it_works: 1. Attacker sends frames with many random source MACs
4. Attacker can sniff all traffic on segment

infrastructure_attacks.description: Advertising false routing information to redirect internet traffic
how_it_works: 1. Attacker announces routes for IP blocks they don't own
3. Traffic for hijacked IPs goes to attacker
infrastructure_attacks.real_example: 2018 cryptocurrency traffic hijacking, 2008 Pakistan YouTube hijack

infrastructure_attacks.description: Using DNS queries/responses to tunnel data or C2 traffic

wireless_attacks.description: Fake access point impersonating legitimate network
Force clients to disconnect from legitimate AP
wireless_attacks.purpose: Capture handshake for cracking, force connection to evil twin

wireless_attacks.description: Brute force WPS PIN to recover WiFi password

key_points: MAC flooding causes switch to broadcast all traffic
BGP hijacking redirects internet traffic at routing level
DNS tunneling uses DNS to bypass firewalls for data exfiltration/C2
Evil twin creates fake AP for MITM attacks
exam_tips: VLAN hopping: switch spoofing or double tagging
MAC flooding fills switch table → broadcasts everything
DNS tunneling = data/C2 over DNS (bypasses firewalls)
Bluejacking = unsolicited messages; Bluesnarfing = data theft
Defense against evil twin: certificate-based WiFi, VPN

knowledge_check.question: An attacker floods a switch with frames containing random source MAC addresses until the switch's MAC table is full. What happens next?
options: The switch broadcasts all traffic to all ports
knowledge_check.explanation: When a switch's MAC table is full (MAC flooding), it 'fails open' and broadcasts frames to all ports instead of forwarding to specific ports. This allows the attacker to sniff all traffic on the segment. Defense: port security with MAC limits.
